abstract: Apple TV may be “an elementary effort” with little content available, but analysts point out that the iPod was also marginal when it was introduced.
snippet: Apple TV may be “an elementary effort” with little content available, but analysts point out that the iPod was also marginal when it was introduced.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  When Steven P. Jobs introduced Apple’s first iPod in 2001, it held more music and was easier to use than the handful of rival products already in the market. But it had a big shortcoming: it worked only with Macintosh computers, then less than 3 percent of the PC market.

headline.main: Apple Faces Many Rivals for Streaming to TVs
headline.print_headline: Apple Faces Many Rivals for Streaming to TVs

abstract: Apple’s stock has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, but no company can grow at that pace forever.
snippet: Apple’s stock has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, but no company can grow at that pace forever.
lead_paragraph: When should investors sell Apple shares? The group’s push overseas and into the business market still holds promise, as does the steady stream of gadgets, like the updated Apple TV introduced by Steven P. Jobs last week. Apple’s trajectory should continue for some time, so its stock, which has gained more than 40 percent each year for the last five, looks attractive at 15 times estimated 2011 earnings. But no company can grow sales at that pace forever. While it may sound premature or even churlish to do so, we offer some strategic cues that could act as warning signs for investors that Apple’s growth is slowing.

headline.main: How to Tell if Apple Falters
headline.print_headline: How to Tell If Apple Falters
